content:
This is a גוף יוצר (guf yotser) piyut from Nusaḥ Candia (Crete) for Shabbat Rosh Ḥodesh Ḥanukkah. The author of the piyut is unknown. It is presented here on the basis of the edition published by Dr. Gabriel Wasserman in his work Liturgical poems of Ḥanukka from Europe (2016), where it appears in Volume 2, as piyut number 23. While the translation below heavily utilizes Dr. Wasserman’s commentary on the piyut, the translation itself is original to me.

I found this piyut when looking through Dr. Wasserman’s aforementioned work, and it struck me as very beautiful and particularly relevant to current events.

Source (Hebrew) Translation (English)
בָּרוּךְ אַתָּה
יְיָ אֱלֹהֵינוּ
מֶלֶךְ הָעוֹלָם
יוֹצֵר אוֹר וּבוֹרֵא חֹשֶׁךְ
עֹשֶׂה שָׁלוֹם וּבוֹרֵא אֶת הַכֹּל
Blessed are you,
Hashem our God,
cosmic majesty,
who forms light and creates darkness,
who makes peace and creates all.[1] Translation added by editor. –ANV 
אוֹר עוֹלָם בְּאוֹצַר חַיִּים
אוֹרוֹת מֵאֹפֶל אָמַר וַיֶּהִי
The Light of the world, the Source of life,
He spoke and out of darkness there came light.[2] Translation added by editor. –ANV 
꙳ ꙳ ꙳
꙳ ꙳ ꙳
אֲנוֹבֵב וְשִׂיחִי אֶשְׁפְּכָה
בְּעַד עֲנֻגָּה וְרַכָּה
בְּשַׁבָּת וְרֹאשׁ חֹֽדֶשׁ וַחֲנֻכָּה
I will speak and pour out my speech,  
In support of the gentle and fragile one[3] Israel 
On Shabbat, and Rosh Ḥodesh, and Ḥanukkah
בְּמוֹעֵצוֹת וּבַשָּׁלִישִׁים
וּבִשְׂמָחוֹת מְשֻׁלָּשִׁים
הִנְחִיל לַקְּדוֹשִׁים
With the triple wisdom[4] Torah, Nevi’im, Ketuvim; from Mishlei 22:20   
And with the three celebrations[5] Shabbat, Rosh Ḥodesh, Ḥanukkah 
That He gave to the holy ones[6] Israel 
גִּיל יוֹם מְנוּחָה
וְיָרֵֽחַ וְשִׂמְחָה
לְגוֹחִי הַלֵּל אַפְצִֽיחָה
With the happiness of the day of rest[7] Shabbat   
And with the moon[8] Rosh Ḥodesh  and celebration[9] Ḥanukkah 
I will exclaim praise for He who took me out[10] of Egypt, or of the womb 
פזמון:
אֲמַלֵּל בְּדָת מְשִׁיבַת
לְנוֹצְרִי כְּבָבַת
מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר לְיוֹם הַשַּׁבָּת
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
I will speak from the renewing law[11] the Torah 
To He who guards me like the pupil[12] of his eye 
A psalm and song for the Shabbat day[13] Psalms 92:1 
O Holy One!
דֻּבׇּֽקוּ כְּאַחַת
שְׁלָשְׁתָּם חֲנֻכָּה וָחֹֽדֶשׁ וְנַֽחַת
שׁוֹמְרֵיהֶם יֻחְשָֽׁכוּ מִשַּֽׁחַת
They are attached like one  
The three of them; Ḥanukkah, the [new] month,[14] Rosh Ḥodesh  and [the day of] pleasure[15] Shabbat 
Those who observe them will be protected from the Pit[16] of Gehinnom 
הַמְּשַׁמְּרִים יוֹם עֲנֻגָּה
יֻצׇּֽלוּ מִדְּאָגָה
וּבְכָל שַׁבָּת לְהִתְעַנְּגָה
Those who observe the gentle day[17] of Shabbat   
Will be saved from worry
And will relax on every Shabbat
וּמְחַשְּׁבֵי חֶשְׁבּוֹן כׇּל חֹֽדֶשׁ
פְּדוּתָם פִּתְאוֹם תְּחַדֵּשׁ
כְּתִקּוּן מִקְדַּשׁ קֹֽדֶשׁ
And those who calculate the months[18] Israel   
Their redemption will be suddenly renewed
As the Holy Temple was founded
פזמון:
וְאַתָּה אֲשֶׁר בִּצְדָקָה נִקְדָּשׁ
יְשׁוּעָה לְעַמְּךָ תְחֻדׇּשׁ
מִזְמוֹר שִֽׁירוּ לַיְיָ שִׁיר חָדָשׁ
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
And You, who is sanctified with justice
Renew salvation for Your nation
A psalm; sing a new song to Hashem[19] Psalms 98:1 
O Holy One!
זְכוֹר עַם בְּךְ חוֹסִים
וְהַצִּילֵם מִיַּד שׁוֹסִים
בַּעֲשׂוֹתְךָ בַּזְּמַן הַזֶּה נִסִּים
Remember the nation who depend on you  
And rescue them from the hands of despoilers
When you do miracles, in these days
חֽוּסָה יְיָ עַל עַם הֲמוֹנַי
וְהַפִּֽילָה אֵשׁ עַל מְעַנַּי
כְּעַל יַד חַשְׁמוֹנַי
Have pity, O Hashem, on the multitudes of my nation  
Bring down fire on my tormentors
As was done at the hand of the Hasmoneans[20] In Dr. Wasserman’s commentary, he suggests that this phrase is actually representing Ḥashmonai as an individual. This is an idea appears in a number of medieval European Jewish sources, where Ḥashmonai is presented as a leader of the revolt alongside Mattathias. In my translation, I have prioritized the resonance of the text to a modern audience over precise accuracy to the presumed intent of the author, and so have translated it as referring to the Hasmoneans collectively. 
טוּב דְּבָרְךָ תָקִים
וְאַל נָשׁוּב רֵקִים
בְּפַלְּלֵֽנוּ לְפָנֶֽיךָ נוֹאֲקִים
Uphold the goodness of Your ways  
And do not leave us to return empty
When we pray before you, calling out
פזמון:
וְנֶחָמוֹת אוֹתָֽנוּ תַזְבִּיד
וּלְךָ מְלוּכָה נַזְבִּיד
מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר חֲנֻכַּת הַבַּֽיִת לְדָוִד
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
And grant us consolations
And we will build You a royal palace
A psalm of David, a song for the dedication of the House[21] Psalms 31:1 
O Holy One!
יָהּ עוֹשֶׂה נִפְלָאוֹת
נְהַדֶּרְךָ בְּמוֹרָאוֹת
עַל פְּעָלְךָ עִמָּֽנוּ נִפְלָאוֹת
God who performs wonders  
We will praise You in awe
For the wonders you perform for us
כּוֹתְבֵי עֲרוּכוֹת וּשְׁמוּרוֹת
מְשַׁבְּחִים לְךְ שִׁירוֹת
עַל עֲשׂוֹתְךָ גְּבוּרוֹת
The writers of the ordered and secured[22] the Torah; from II Samuel 23:5   
Praise you with songs
For the great deeds You did
לוֹמְדֵי שַׁעֲשׁוּעוֹת
מִתְחַנְּנִים בְּשַׁוְעוֹת
וּמַזְכִּירִים אֶת הַתְּשׁוּעוֹת
The ones who study delights[23] the Torah   
They call out in prayer
And remember the salvations
פזמון:
אֲמַלֵּל בְּדָת מְשִׁיבַת
לְנוֹצְרִי כְּבָבַת
מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר לְיוֹם הַשַּׁבָּת
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
I will speak from the renewing law[24] the Torah 
To He who guards me like the pupil[25] of his eye 
A psalm and song for the Shabbat day[26] Psalms 92:1 
O Holy One!
מְשַׁנְּנֵי חׇכְמוֹת
עֵינֵיהֶם בִּימִין רוֹמֵמוֹת
וּמְתַנִּים עֲשׂוֹת מִלְחָמוֹת
Those who learn wisdom[27] Israel   
Their eyes are on [Your] exalted Right Hand
They declare that they will go to war[28] and be victorious 
נֶגְדְּךָ עֵינֵֽינוּ
סְכוֹת צַעֲקָתֵֽנוּ
כִּי כָל טוּב עָשִֽׂיתָ עִמָּֽנוּ
Our eyes are to You  
To hear our cries
For you have done with us only good
סַגֵּף כׇּל שׂוֹנְאֵֽינוּ
וְהַכְחֵד כׇּל מְעַנֵּֽנוּ
וַעֲשֵׂה לָֽנוּ כַּאֲשֶׁר עָשִֽׂיתָ לַאֲבוֹתֵֽינוּ
Afflict all those who hate us  
And destroy all those who torment us
And do for us like You did for our ancestors
פזמון:
וְאַתָּה אֲשֶׁר בִּצְדָקָה נִקְדָּשׁ
יְשׁוּעָה לְעַמְּךָ תְחֻדׇּשׁ
מִזְמוֹר שִֽׁירוּ לַיְיָ שִׁיר חָדָשׁ
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
And You, who is sanctified with justice
Renew salvation for Your nation
A psalm; sing a new song to Hashem[29] Psalms 98:1 
O Holy One!
עֱנוּתֵֽנוּ אַל תִּבְזֶה
מִמָּרוֹם אוֹתָֽנוּ תֶחֶזֶה
כְּבַֽטְתָּ בַּזְּמַן הַזֶּה
Do not reject our suffering  
Observe us from above
As you said [you would do] at this time
פּוֹדֶה תָּחִישׁ יְשׁוּעָה
וּבְךָ נִשְׁתַּעְשְׁעָה
בְּאַבֶּדְךָ מַלְכוּת יָוָן הָרְשָׁעָה
O Redeemer, bring salvation  
And we will delight in you
Like when you destroyed the wicked kingdom of Greece
צְפֶה צִדְקוֹתֵֽינוּ
וּסְכוֹת נַאֲקוֹתֵֽינוּ
וְהוֹשִׁיעֵֽנוּ בְּעֵת צָרָתֵֽנוּ
View our righteousness  
And hear our pained exclamations
And save us in our time of trouble
פזמון:
וְנֶחָמוֹת אוֹתָֽנוּ תַזְבִּיד
וּלְךָ מְלוּכָה נַזְבִּיד
מִזְמוֹר שִׁיר חֲנֻכַּת הַבַּֽיִת לְדָוִד
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
And grant us consolations
And we will build You a royal palace
A psalm of David, a song for the dedication of the House[30] Psalms 31:1 
O Holy One!
קָדוֹשׁ רַֽבְתָּ רִיבָם
וְשָׁכַֽנְתָּ בְקִרְבָּם
וְנִחַֽמְתָּ אֶת לִבָּם
O Holy One, you fought their fights  
And You dwelt in their midst[31] in the rededicated Temple 
And You comforted their hearts
רִחַֽמְתָּ הֲמוֹנָם
הַמְיַחֲדִים בְּעִנְיָנָם
וְדַֽנְתָּ אֶת דִּינָם
You had mercy on their multitudes  
Who exclaimed Your oneness
And You judged their cause
שָׁמַֽעְתָּ שַׁוְעָתָם
חָמַֽלְתָּ עַל עֲדָתָם
וְנָקַֽמְתָּ אֶת נִקְמָתָם
You heard their cries  
You had pity on their congregation
And You avenged their vengeance
פזמון:
תּוֹפִֽיעַ לְשַׁמֵּֽחַ עַמְּךָ
וּלְכוֹנֵן בֵּית אוּלָמְּךָ
וּנְפָאֶרְךָ וּנְרוֹמֶמְךָ
קָדוֹשׁ
refrain:
Appear, to make Your nation rejoice  
And to establish the House of Your Hall[32] the Temple 
And we will praise you and exalt you
O Holy One!
꙳ ꙳ ꙳
꙳ ꙳ ꙳
הַכֹּל יוֹדוּךָ וְהַכֹּל יְשַׁבְּחוּךָ וְהַכֹּל יֹאמְרוּ אֵין קָדוֹשׁ כַּיְְיָ…
All thank you, all praise you, all declare: There is none holy like Hashem…[33] Translation added by editor. –ANV 

This yotser for Shabbat Rosh Ḥodesh Ḥanukkah is found in two manuscripts: MS. Canonici Or. 49A/2, fol. 10r (Oxford Bodleian 1083): a Maḥzor according to the Romaniote rite (Ḥanukah-Tishah be-Av) (ff. 7r-182v). The text is also found in a manuscript at the Montefiore Library (London, England) Ms. 220 (F 5190) (on page 9).
